Reflections on Chroma

12/26/2017

When I decided I wanted to make a mobile game, all the programming knowledge I had came from a month of self-taught Java fundamentals and two weeks of Android Studio tutorials on Youtube. This meant that I didn’t have many options when it came to what kind of game I was going to make. I could set up a button, listen for gestures, and navigate to a new screen.

First Build

As a result, the first build of Chroma was little more than a set of buttons and a few different screens. The game had a simple premise: tap the color that the word says to move on to the next round. I tried to make it more challenging by having the font color be a different color from the word each time, as well. As a side note, this has actually been psychologically studied – it’s called the Stroop effect. Overall though, this iteration of the game went smoothly.

I opted for a minimalist aesthetic mostly because I didn’t know enough to design it any other way

The Rework

A few weeks later, I revisited Chroma and decided to polish it some more. I actually really enjoyed this process since I could judge my old work – kind of like when you dig up an essay from eighth grade and wonder what was going through your past self’s brain. I reworked the color-and-text-randomizing-algorithm, revamped the UI, and picked out some royalty-free music I found online.

Some snazzy new animations, a new game mode, and an actual timer


Getting the music to work right was probably the biggest challenge I faced in this whole project. MediaPlayer objects don’t play well with the Android activity life cycle so I was getting a lot of strange behaviors, like multiple instances of the music starting, and the music not stopping when a user exited the app. Audio focus was also an issue – the game’s music wasn’t ducking when other apps on the smartphone started playing sound (say an incoming phone call). After two days of Googling and experimenting, I eventually was able to solve all these problems by manually tracking mute settings and changes in the life cycle.

Final Remarks

I actually had a ton of fun making Chroma – even though it was super frustrating at times. As for the learning experience, developing an app taught me a lot that no online tutorial ever could. Though it wasn’t a huge project, I know I improved a lot as a programmer by having done it.


If you want to check out how the game plays, you can check out Chroma on the Google Play Store or you can see the code for yourself on my Github.
